g.title: Rectangle
g.text: Observer (=Dependents, Publish-Subscribe)Define a one-to-many dependency between objects so that when one object changes state, all its dependents are notified and updated automatically.

g.title: Rectangle.119
g.desc: The exact (number of) objects that need to be notified, when ...
g.text: The exact (number of) objects that need to be notified, when a given object changes state, is priorly unknown

g.title: Folded Corner.196
g.desc: The Observer pattern both entails the negative and positive a...

g.text: The Observer pattern both entails the negative and positive aspects of the Open Closed principle. The Observer pattern uses abstractions for both Subject and Observer to gain flexibility and stability. However, abstractions introduce an additional form of indirection. Indirection has negative impact on the navigability and debuggability of the code. Imagine interconnecting a Sender and Receiver object. A concrete Sender can be coupled to a concrete Receiver directly, resulting in tight coupling, but minimal indirection. A more flexible alternative is to invert the dependency by ensuring that Sender is dependent on abstract Receiver. This results in lower coupling, but a ‘higher’ from of indirection. The final alternative is the Observer pattern, where the Sender allows attachment and detachment of more then one Receiver. This results in even lower coupling, because it does not only provide decouplement in the type of Receiver, but also in the number of Receivers. Why not always apply the Observer pattern when the Sender (=Subject) already depends on an abstract Receiver (=Observer)? Because the Attach and Detach functionality (=collection management) of the Observer pattern add additional maintenance and complexity to the Subject!

g.title: Folded Corner.235
g.desc: The Observer design pattern provides a subscription-model. Su...

g.text: The Observer design pattern provides a subscription-model. Such a model consist of a publisher, that broadcasts information, and a subscriber, that listens to this broadcast. The publisher is called the Subject and the subscriber is called the Observer. The Subject changes state because of an external stimulus. It then notifies its Observers, whom in return request more detailed information from the Subject. The Subject provides functionality to attach and detach abstract Observers. This abstraction enables the possibility to attach new concrete observers with relative ease (as long as they are following the Observer abstraction). As a result, the Subject does not require any change to support a new kind or more Observers. This enables unfamiliarity with the type and number of dependencies during development of the Subject, which ensures independent development in different layers of the software architecture.

g.title: Folded Corner.258
g.desc: The Observer design pattern compliments the Open Closed princ...

g.text: The Observer design pattern compliments the Open Closed principle by allowing new receivers (=Observers) to attach to an existing sender (=Subjects) without change of existing code. The Open Closed Principle is supported by the Dependency inversion principle; both Subjects and Observers dependent on abstractions. This has positive impact on the stability, reusability and testability of the code. All aspect are compared against an implementation where Subjects and Observers reference each other directly (no abstraction) and their multiplicity is statically defined. Stability, because the existing Subjects and Observers do not require change in production or test code in case of extension. An existing Subject does not require change incase the number or type of Observers change. This is realized by the Attach and Detach functionality in combination with the Subject being dependent on an abstract Observer. An existing Observer does not require change in case the type of Subject changes. This is realized by the Observer being dependent on an abstract Subject. Reusability, both Observer and Subject are dependent on an abstraction making them reusable with different concrete Observers and Subject(s). Testability, the inverted dependency, Observers and Subjects being dependent on abstractions, allows mock-ability and thus improves testability of the code.

g.title: Rectangle.261
g.desc: A runtime solution to subscribe and unsubscribe objects listi...
g.text: A runtime solution to subscribe and unsubscribe objects listing to other objects

g.title: Folded Corner.265
g.desc: The Observer design pattern enables the possibility to Attach...

g.text: The Observer design pattern enables the possibility to Attach and Detach objects to other objects during runtime. The Subject interface has Attach and Detach functionality that enables Observer(s) to couple and decouple. A requirement might be that Observers should listen only for a limited amount of time or only in specific cases to certain Subjects. The Observer pattern enables dynamically controlling the dependency model in your code to realize such behavior.
